activity.title: beckn/beckn-ui-workspace#4063
activity.text: Specification: Registry specification /subscriber API improvement

activity.title: beckn/beckn-ui-workspace#4058
activity.text:
Update:

1. As per the current Registry Specification, the /subscribe call response from the Registry is { “status”: “<current_status>“}
2. It was suggested that the response to a /subscribe call should be an ACK as is used in Protocol-Specification API.  These suggestions were based on a discussion between Ravi and Faiz.
2. Had a call with Ravi to clarify the same. He instructed that sending { “status”: “<current_status>“} in response to a /subscribe call is fine. He will discuss it internally with Faiz.

activity.title: beckn/protocol-specifications#477
activity.text:
Date: 12th April, 2025

Current Status:

1. Had a discussion with Venky on Saturday, 12th April.
2. He had taken a look at the detailed API document that I had created.
3. Suggested that we dont include too much details in out registry implementation guide which we are providing to the implementors. We agreed to keep the implementation guide abstract.
4. We dont need to explicitly cover the extra implementation details that Venkys registry has in our implementation guide.

Next steps:

1. Based on the discussion, I will create a API implementation guide for subscribe and on_subscribe in Beckn Registry.

activity.title: beckn/beckn-ui-workspace#3619
activity.text:
Date 11th April

Current Status:

1. In order to allow partial deliver of items from an order. we do not need any change in the specification.
2. Retail BPP can send the package count, package weights of the partial items, retail order id to which these items belong the logistics BPP.
3. logistics BPP creates a logistic order ID.
4. overall a logistics order would have 3 major details
    - retail order id
    - logistics order id
    - package details
5. The retail BPP can create as many logistics order as they want using the above approach.

activity.title: beckn/beckn-ui-workspace#3619
activity.text:
Have been doing some research on how the delivery service work in general. below is a summary.

In most cases, the delivery service doesn't need the full product specification, but rather enough details to handle the package appropriately. 

**Essential Information:**
Physical Attributes: **Weight, dimensions, and possibly the number of packages**. This information helps with logistics planning (e.g., vehicle selection and load balancing).

**Basic Description:** 
A brief description or SKU can be useful for identification and handling instructions, especially if certain items require special care (e.g., **fragile or hazardous items**).

Detailed product specs (e.g., color, model, detailed technical specifications) are generally not required for the delivery process.
The focus is on shipment handling rather than the specifics of what is being sold.


**Industry Practices:**

1. Shipping Documents: Often include a packing list or invoice that provides detailed information, but the delivery order itself contains only the necessary physical parameters and basic identifiers.
2. Efficiency: Keeping the delivery request lightweight and focused on logistical requirements helps in processing orders faster and reduces the chance for errors.

activity.title: beckn/missions#261
activity.text:
10th Mar 2025:

1. Went through the outcome visualisation doc shared by Pooja to understand the use case. (link in the ticket description)
2. Had a call with Kavya from solar square to discuss the use case, requirements, demo of current application.

Next steps:

1. Kavya to share an excel sheet with the parameters that are relevant for discovery, catalog etc.
2. They are planning to implement it multiple phases.
3. The current phase will have the discovery and booking of solar panel installation service providers.
4. In the later phase, they plan to include subsidy, financing, and IOT telemetry  features as well in the network.
